Class FSMTransition

This class represents a single "transition rule" in your FSM (Finite State Machine) blueprint. Think of it as a specific pathway üõ§Ô∏è that tells your FSM how to move from one "state" (like "Idle") to another "state" (like "Running").

Syntax
public class FSMTransition
Remarks

Each transition rule has three main parts:

  • From:The starting state.
  • To:The ending state.
  • Condition:A special check that must be true for the transition to happen.

While you'll often create these transitions easily using the FSMBuilder, this class is made public for more advanced users who might need to load FSM definitions from files or perform very specific tweaks.

Constructors

| Edit this page View Source

FSMTransition(string, string, Func<IStateContext, bool>)

Creates a new transition rule for your FSM blueprint.

Declaration
public FSMTransition(string from, string to, Func<IStateContext, bool> condition)
Parameters
Type Name Description
string from

The name of the state this transition starts from.
string to

The name of the state this transition moves to.
Func<IStateContext, bool> condition

The function that decides if this transition should happen.
Remarks

When you create a transition, you must tell it:

  • Where it starts (`from`):The state you're leaving.
  • Where it goes (`to`):The state you're entering.
  • What makes it happen (`condition`):The rule that must be true.
Exceptions
Type Condition
ArgumentException

This happens if the from or to state names are empty or just spaces. It means you haven't given valid names for the states.
ArgumentNullException

This happens if you don't provide a condition (it's null). A transition always needs a rule to decide when to move.

Properties

| Edit this page View Source

Condition

This is the condition (a function that returns true or false) that must be true for this transition to actually happen.

Declaration
public Func<IStateContext, bool> Condition { get; set; }
Property Value
Type Description
Func<IStateContext, bool>
Remarks

This function receives an IStateContext, which provides important information about the FSM's current situation, helping the condition decide if the transition should occur.

ToString()

Gives a simple text description of this transition rule.

Declaration
public override string ToString()
Returns
Type Description
string

A string that looks like "StartingState --[Condition]--> EndingState". It helps you quickly see what the transition does.
